story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsJean-Claude Juncker tries to claim credit for ideaClick to followThe IndependentThe European Commission has said it is “delighted” that the leaders of France and Germany have backed the creation of a “real” EU army.A spokesperson for the commission’s president Jean-Claude Juncker said he was “pleased” that the argument for the force seemed to be “going in our direction”.Addressing the European Parliament on Tuesday Angela Merkel said she supported a “real, true” European army, echoing an identical call by her French counterpart Emmanuel Macron the week before.Angela Merkel calls for creation of ‘real, true’ EU armySpeaking on Wednesday, the commission’s spokesperson tried to attribute credit for the idea to Mr Juncker, noting that he had previously endorsed such a force.“Let me clarify that the first one who spoke about the EU army four years ago was someone called Jean-Claude Juncker,” they said.“Memory is short nowadays in Brussels and the capitals but people here present, you are aware of who launched this idea.”The spokesperson added: “We are delighted that both the president of the French republic and the German chancellor, with a few days interval, publicly backed this idea.Trump taunts Macron in world war jibe: ‘How’d it work out for France’Emmanuel Macron calls for creation of a ‘true European army’Lord Guthrie switches to Leave over European armyA European army is exactly what the EU and UK needs“We have many times explained how we see these things: this is a commission that wants Europe to have a meaningful defence identity.”The spokesperson noted that the commission had “proposed a significant increase in new EU resources for defence” in the coming budget.The proposals for a European military have triggered a new spat with US president Donald Trump, who took offence to a suggestion by Mr Macron that such a force could ensure Europe’s security in the shadow of the United States.The French president made his call during a radio interview last week: “We have to protect ourselves with respect to China, Russia and even the United States of America.Let me clarify that the first one who spoke about the EU army four years ago was someone called Jean-Claude&nbspJuncker“We will not protect the Europeans unless we decide to have a true European army.”He added: “When I see President Trump announcing that he’s quitting a major disarmament treaty which was formed after the 1980s Euro-missile crisis that hit Europe, who is the main victim? Europe and its security.”The suggestion angered Mr Trump, who sent a series of hostile tweets about the comments.On Tuesday the US president tweeted: “Emmanuel Macron suggests building its own army to protect Europe against the US, China and Russia. But it was Germany in World Wars One &amp Two – How did that work out for France? They were starting to learn German in Paris before the US came along. Pay for Nato or not!”The election of Mr Trump to the White House appears to have given more urgency to the cause of boosting the EU’s defence capabilities, with leaders warning they cannot simply rely on the United States.Commission president Mr Juncker said last year that “deference to Nato can no longer be used as a convenient alibi to argue against greater European efforts”.In 2016, then defence secretary Sir Michael Fallon said the UK would use its veto to stop the creation of any EU army. story: A Brexit deal had been agreed at a technical level, by both UK and EU officials, it has been confirmed.&nbspDowning Street last night issued a statement: Cabinet will meet at 2pm tomorrow to consider the draft agreement the negotiating teams have reached in Brussels, and to decide on next steps. Cabinet ministers have been invited to read documentation ahead of that meeting.&nbsp                Brexit deal: Will Brexit withdrawal agreement be signed TOMORROW?Last minute talks between the UK and EU seem to have made headway in agreeing a draft document for exiting the EU.As the news broke, ministers immediatly headed to the Commons to air their views on the prospective deal.Many have slammed the new deal as BRINO - Brexit in Name Only - blasting the deal as a sell out to the EU.Both the UK and EU want to schedule a summit of European leaders at the end of November to sign off the withdrawal deal.If the Cabinet agrees to the Prime Minister's proposals today, a Brexit summit will take place on November 24 and 25.&nbspBrexit talks appear to have taken a step forward as Theresa May calls an emergency Cabinet meeting (Image: )What is Brino? What does Brino mean?Brino means 'Brexit in name only' and was coined by Jacob Rees Mogg.In an interview with the Independent in January 2018 MP Jacob Rees-Mogg declared: &ldquoIf everything is delayed for two years and then there&rsquos high alignment you will find that by 2022 no one will have noticed any difference from having left.&ldquoThen what will be the point of voting for the party that&rsquos implemented it. I&rsquom against &lsquoBrino&rsquo.                Brexit deal done: DUP warns May deal will be &lsquovery hard sell&rsquo                 What is the ERG? Who is the Brexit group trying to stop Brexit deal?The Prime Minister now faces the daunting task of getting the Cabinet to agree to her deal (Image: )Brino is a version of leaving the European Union that would mean staying in the EU customs union andor single market, with a very long or indefinite transition period.It is also known as a soft Brexit.Theresa May now faces the task of persuading the Cabinet to agree with her plan in order to progress and guarentee a summit at the end of November.This is easier said than done as the Cabinet is reportedly deeply ided over the Prime Minister&rsquos plan.Jacob Rees-Mogg has told the BBC he opposes the Prime Minister's plan (Image: )Mr Rees-Mogg has today slammed Theresa May's deal with the EU&nbspas a betrayal.The leading Brexiteer politician pledged to vote against the deal, before bluntly adding: I&nbsphope the Cabinet will block it and I hope Parliament will block it.ITV's Carl Dinnen tweeted last night: The DUP have not seen the detail on the new proposed Withdrawal Agreement but suggest that without significant change from what was outlined in last week&rsquos letter it is not likely to be something they could support.Irish broadcaster RTE said the orce deal text was agreed late on Monday and then passed on to London, quoting sources as saying it was as stable as it can be.

story: Two years after Britain voted to leave the European Union, it was announced that both the EU and UK have come for an agreement on the final Brexit deal. The draft Brexit deal, a 500-page document expected to be released on Wednesday evening, has already faced widespread criticism. Both the UK and EU have devised a working solution for the backstop, the insurance policy to prevent a hard border on the island of Ireland. But in a bid to get a Brexit deal agreed with the Brussels bloc, the Prime Minister is expected have signed up to the possibility of a permanent customs union with the EU, unless a better deal is reached within two years.&nbsp                Brexit BETRAYAL: Angela Merkel's role in David Cameron calling EU vote                May struggles as Brexiteer warns she is losing MILLIONS of votersDuring a heated debate with Sky News&rsquo Adam Boulton, Tory MP Andrew Bridgen said: &ldquoWe actually won&rsquot be leaving, will we? We are not going to be leaving the customs union.Bolton hit back and said: &ldquoWell, we will be. We will no longer be members of the European Union. We will be no longer members of the political structures.The Tory MP insisted Britain would be in a &ldquoworse situation and remain to be a &ldquovassal state by taking EU laws.Boulton replied: &ldquoWell, that&rsquos your problem. You&rsquore the one that wanted to leave in the first place.Brexit news: Andrew Bridgen questions the relevance of Liam Fox's ministerial role (Image: Sky News)&ldquoI mean, even Boris Johnson says we will be in a worse state and for the first time we won&rsquot have influence. But that&rsquos what people who voted Leave wanted to do. They wanted to leave that political structure.Mr Bridgen said: &ldquoBut not stay under their laws. That&rsquos not leaving. It is?The Sky News host shouted: &ldquoIt is leaving.The Tory MP said: &ldquoSo, we are going to leave but stay under their laws and laws are not going to be made in this place, they are going to be made in Brussels and we are not going to have any input anymore.The pair began to debate trade post-Brexit and Mr Bridgen said: &ldquoIt&rsquos very anti-competitive - no free trade deals. The big benefit of Brexit is going those trade deals.Bolton fired back: &ldquoSo you don&rsquot think this is going to fly?In response, Mr Bridgen blasted: &ldquoWhat's the point of Liam Fox&rsquos department for International Trade?Mr Boulton chuckled and said: &ldquoWell, that&rsquos a different question.Mr Bridgen concluded and said: &ldquoI&rsquom hoping that the Cabinet will explain to the Prime Minister that this is not acceptable and won&rsquot go through Parliament. If not, it will fall to principle Members of Parliament to stand up for the democratic mandate we are given by the referendum to leave the European Union to oppose this deal.The Department for International Trade has been contacted by Express for comment.

title: jesus christ discovery bible archaeology what did jesus look like
story: &lsquoIt was Jesus looking at us&rsquo Historians find drawing of Christ at his baptism (Image: DROR MAAYAN &bull )The art-piece depicting Jesus Christ was discovered in an ancient church in southern Israel in the ancient town of Shivta. The drawing date back almost 1800 years, and it gives the world a different look at Jesus. Christ is often depicted as almost western-looking, with long, straight flowing hair and chiseled features.                BIBLE BREAKTHROUGH: Lost city of Zer where Jesus fed masses UNCOVERED                Shroud of Turin SHOCKING revelation DISMISSES link to Jesus ChristHowever, in this image a young Jesus Christ is painted clean shaven with curly hair and a long, thin nose.Archaeologists have been digging through the region for more than a century, and the image of Christ was actually first spotted in 1920.However, at the time experts were unaware what they were looking at and left it and forgot about it.Recently, thanks to modern technology, experts rediscovered the drawing and played a sort of archaeological game of dot-to-dot to reconstruct the once prominent image.Emma Maayan-Fanar from the University of Haifa told Haaretz: I was there at the right time, at the right place with the right angle of light and, suddenly, I saw eyes.The drawing supposedly depicts Christ (Image: DROR MAAYAN)It was the face of Jesus at his baptism, looking at us.There has been much debate over what Jesus actually looked like, with most artwork making him seem western yet his appearance is not mentioned in any of the Gospels.Joan Taylor, a historian who has been attempting to chronicle the life of Jesus Christ, has reconstructed what she believes Jesus would have looked like by analysing historical text, and skeletal records from the Middle East.She claims he would have been a short man who looked Middle Eastern, as opposed to the commonly depicted white man, which would have been unrealistic for the region at the time.Ms Taylor wrote for the : &ldquoWhat I have learnt is that Judaeans of this time were closest biologically to Iraqi Jews of the contemporary world.&ldquoIn terms of a colour palette then, think dark-brown to black hair, deep brown eyes, olive-brown skin. Jesus would have been a man of Middle Eastern appearance.&ldquoIn terms of height, an average man of this time stood 166 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall.

title: Brexit deal news explained UK EU withdrawal agreement Theresa May Ireland backstop latest
story: The Prime Minister&rsquos latest proposals have already become deeply controversial with rumours of more ministerial resignations and Northern Ireland&rsquos Democratic Unionist Party ready to vote down the withdrawal agreement. But in what is considered largely as a victory by Brussels and Downing Street, Mrs May has secured a UK-wide Irish backstop, the insurance policy to prevent a hard border on the island of Ireland. The mechanism became Brexit&rsquos most vexed issue because the EU&rsquos own plan was used as the building blocks for what was agreed by the Prime Minister&rsquos Europe advisor Olly Robbins and his European Commission counterparts Michel Barnier and Sabine Weyand. After proclaiming &ldquono British Prime Minister could accept the terms set out by Brussels, which would have essentially kept Northern Ireland locked in the EU&rsquos customs union and single market for goods, Mrs May has now agreed a UK-wide approach to the backstop.                Brexit news: Customs union membership is now 'basis for the future'                Brexit deal TODAY: What time will Cabinet meet TODAY?When does the Irish backstop come into force?As it stands, the mechanism will now take shape in the withdrawal agreement as a UK-wide customs union arrangement.This temporary insurance policy will come into force &ldquounless and until a permanent solution to prevent a hard Irish border is found jointly by Brussels and Westminster.Because of the toxicity in the backstop, negotiators have included a review mechanism to avoid it ever being triggered.In July 2020, officials from both sides will come together to make a decision of how to proceed using three potential options.They will either say a UK-EU free trade agreement that avoids a hard Irish border has been agreed and the backstop is no longer needed, if a solution is within reach they can extend the 21-month transition period to allow more time for talks and finally, if all else fails, the backstop will be triggered.Brexit news: Theresa May agrees deal with EU and now must convince her Cabinet (Image: )Will the UK be chained to Brussels forever?Fearful Brexiteers believe allowing a UK-wide customs backstop with no &ldquoindependent review mechanism would allow Brussels to essentially keep Britain locked in a start of constant limbo.Under the terms of the UK-wide backstop, Britain would be in a customs union with Brussels and therefore have to follow EU trade rules and be unable to sign independent trade deals in order to maintain a frictionless border.The rumoured backstop agreement can be described as a swimming pool &ndash Great Britain would be in the shallow end while Northern Ireland is in the deep.The EU has insisted the original Northern Ireland-specific backstop is buried deep within the 500-page withdrawal agreement.In theory, this means if the UK Government grows sick of following EU trade rules and customs union membership it could remove Great Britain from backstop but the ultimate fallback would come into play and Northern Ireland would remain solely in the EU&rsquos customs arrangement and single market for goods &ndash creating a border in the Irish Sea.                What is the Brexit backstop? Has Northern Ireland been split from UK?                 Brexit deal TODAY: What time will Cabinet meet TODAY?Does this mean the European Court of Justice will have influence in Britain?Ultimately, the ECJ will be the final arbiter on issues involving EU law that may arise from the Irish backstop agreement.Geoffrey Cox, the Attorney General, has discussed a &ldquojoint arbitration panel to break any future impasse during review negotiations surrounding the backstop.But EU officials believe such panels are not allowed to settle political disputes of this nature.Questions of interpreting EU law can only be settled by the ECJ, which will leave the Luxembourg-based courts with an important role to play in the UK&rsquos exit from the backstop.Could the backstop become the future trading deal?Michel Barnier&rsquos deputy Sabine Weyand told EU27 ambassadors last Friday that the UK-wide customs arrangement would become the &ldquobasis of the future relationship.She said: &ldquoWe should be in the best negotiation position for the future relationship.&ldquoThis requires the customs union as the basis of the future relationship.&ldquoThey must align their rules but the EU will retain all controls. They apply the same rules.&ldquoThe UK wants a lot more from the future relationship, so EU retains its leverage.Obviously this is still all to play for, but Brussels feels like it is in a strong negotiating position moving forward.

story: People are not putting enough by to have a happy retirement (Image: Getty)It says Britons should aim for a pension pot equal to one times their annual household income by the time they are 30, two times by the time they are 40, increasing to seven times by 68.To achieve that, people need to save 13 percent a year between the ages of 25 and 68.And experts say they already have a head start with workplace auto-enrollment.From April 2019 employers will contribute at least three percent, with employees saving five percent of salary before tax.This means they only need an extra five percent to reach a 13 per cent savings rate.Most retirees need to replace between 55 and 85 percent of their earnings because they do not spend as much money &ndash and state pensions boost the pot.The research found that those earning between &pound30,000 and &pound120,000 at retirement should plan for their retirement savings to replace about 35 percent of this before tax.Maike Currie, the investment director at Fidelity, said yesterday: While UK savers need to save less than other countries, there is still a lot more that could be done to educate the population to save for their retirement.Auto-enrolment has had a real impact, with almost three quarters of employees contributing to a pension, and employers have a significant role to play in engaging their workforce.However, the onus is still on iniduals to make sure they're saving enough.------------------Half of young want to quit job earlyNearly half of young people hope to retire early despite not saving for later life.A new study says 47 per cent of under-35s reckon they will be able to stop work before their 60s.But two-thirds are not even saving for retirement while just four per cent expect to be grafting after 70.                Can you defer your state pension? Why it&rsquos worth delaying                 Express crusade: War widow pension taken away because she fell in loveAmong those aged 55 or more, 14 percent expect to be working into their 70s and 68 per cent are stashing cash away for their old age.Robert Szechenyi, of Rathbones Investment Management, said: It's concerning that, despite a lack of savings, half of millennials are expecting to retire early.If you are planning to retire before or at 60, then this could mean you need to fund yourself for 30 or more years.Joana Freitas doesn't want to go into an office at 70 (Image: Tim Clarke)Case Study: &lsquoI don't want work at 70&rsquoJoana Freitas, 29, said: I don't mind working until I'm 65 but I don't want to be heading into the office when I'm 70 or even older.The executive assistant from Barnet, north London, said that the Government and pensions industry should be louder and clearer about the importance of saving for old age.Sorting out a pension is complicated, she said. Where do I get the right information?I joined auto-enrolment at work because they made it easy for me and I'm responsible enough to know I have to do something.

Every day seems to bring new tales of criminals getting away scot-free.It’s no surprise we’ve lost control of our streets, not just in the capital, but across the country — where kne crime is increasing at a HIGHER rate than in London.Politicians must do more than hope to plug the dam with a bit more cash. They must rebuild a ing force.That may well involve moving mental health responsibilities to another arm of government, or slashing the bureaucracy police are stuck with.It may even be time for an independent commission to look at policing.But this sorry state of affairs shames our nation — and leaves us all vulnerable.“AT the going down of the sun, and in the morning, we will remember them...”The lines of the famous war poem have never been as true as they are this weekend,  years on from the end of an awful conflict that took millions of lives. There are some who say that a century later we should consign this conflict to history. We respectfully disagree.We must keep on teaching the war’s horrors and of the reconciliation since. From a continent that tore itself apart twice in just four decades, Europe is now bound by common and friendly ties — no matter whether a country is an EU member or not.On Sunday that will be made abundantly clear when the German president lays a wreath at the Cenotaph.It is a fitting gesture of remembrance, and of progress.JO Johnson is entitled to his view that the PM’s Brexit deal is a bit of a mess.We share many of his concerns. Mrs May has a way to go to convince us she really is bringing us true independence.But his call for a second referendum is deeply dangerous. The people have had their say.They would not take kindly to being told to change their minds by the very political elites they turned against the first time.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: labour mp lives in social housing
story: Shadow development secretary Kate Osamor has faced intense criticism after it emerged that she promoted her son in his House of Commons job, regardless of his conviction for having £, of Class A drugs with intent to supply at Bestival in Dorset last year.Now the Sun on Sunday can reveal that Ms Osamor and her son Ishmael, , are living in social housing in Tottenham, north London - despite their earnings classing them ineligible by council guidelines.Haringey Council documents from  state that households earning in excess of £, are not eligible to apply for a social housing property.And it has been reported that , people are waiting for social housing in the borough - one of the poorest in Britain - and a further , are living in temporary accommodation due to the limited supply of properties.Ms Osamor, a close ally of Jeremy Corbyn, is paid a salary of £, plus expenses. title: stop praying silence from charles
story: But close your eyes and imagine, for a moment, knowing from childhood exactly what job you are going to do — because you have no choice about whether or not you actually want to do it.And imagine, then, having to wait for that job to start until you are the age when most people are hanging up their work boots and starting to claim a pension.It’s impossible, right  But the Prince of Wales — the man who was born to be king — has known since the age of four that he would one day have to step into his mother’s shoes. And what a mother.They say no one is irreplaceable but I think she is — which must be such a lot of pressure for him. In short, he has spent his entire le waiting for his mum to die before he can start his dream job.And in the meantime his le, in some ways, is on hold. He was not allowed to marry the woman he loved and was instead forced into a loveless marriage.And every time he so much as expresses an opinion about anything, he is denounced as being “meddling”.So it’s no wonder that in Prince, Son And Heir, the BBC documentary this week marking his th birthday, Charles was quick to quell concerns that he would be a “meddling” or activist king, saying: “I’m not that stupid.”Declaring the role of sovereign and heir to be dferent, he said he is aware of the constraints he will encounter as king, and says his behaviour will change.I can see why he is saying that, given the amount of criticism that has come his way over the years. But when you think that he was campaigning about issues such as the environment and single-use plastic long before anyone  got on the bandwagon, it might be better to see him as a trailblazer than a meddler.I admire that he has a voice.And when he is king I think he should use it — not be silenced by the pressure of the role.He has a very broad range of knowledge and he is absolutely passionate. We live in a society where everyone has their say — so why shouldn’t he In fact, I thinkhe visited Europe he might help with Brexit.There is no doubt the Queen is a hard act to follow — when the time comes, that is. Now Charles is  he is the longest serving heir to the throne in history. And he may have years to go, as the Queen looks and sounds fantastic .But we should stop maligning Charles and start supporting him.He is a good man and there is no doubt he is dedicated to the job. He is mature enough to know how to do the job well and he certainly knows what is expected of him.He has brought up two fantastic sons that any parent would be proud of.And he really is passionate about changing the world for the better.It has been more than  years since he set up his Prince’s Trust charity.Last year alone it helped nearly , young people get into education, training and jobs. It is simply fantastic.He is deeply committed to his fantastic we, who is very down-to-earth and great fun .He is also passionate about promoting women’s issues, so whatever you think of him you must give him credit for that.I believe very strongly in the monarchy. I would do anything the Queen asked me to do.The Royal Family are a great thing for our country and something to be very proud of.In a world of increasing uncertainty, they are this country’s rock and foundation. We should all get behind Charles and celebrate him as our future king.Apart from anything , we need all the stability we can get. ANYONE living in London will be unsurprised to hear that there are now a record number of people sleeping rough there.Figures show there were , rough sleepers in the capital between July and September – the first time the total has exceeded , in a three-month period.It’s awful and it’s shocking to see people sitting in the cold begging for money.And it’s hard to know how to help. Of course, the temptation is to give money but obviously that’s just a short-term fix.Night shelters are a good short-term solution. Buthomeless people don’t get involved with a network that can really help them, it’s unlikely their circumstances will ever change.My husband Paul volunteers with the fantastic charity West London Mission . It offers homeless people a hot shower, new clothes, a meal and a decent night’s sleep.But it also offers access to project workers who will help people change their circumstances.Its aim is to empower and help homeless people become part of a community, because that’s the start of them getting off the streets, into accommodation, then into work.There are so many reasons that people become homeless. Some have lost their job and can’t afford rent, or they’ve fallen out with family and turn to drink and drugs.They might have mental or physical health problems, a history of abuse or a dficult childhood moving between foster homes.But where there is le, there is hope. Paul has been working with one guy who was homeless and hopelessly addicted to drugs.But, over time, he has got clean, found a place to live and, last week, got a job at a restaurant, which is what he was doing before he got involved in drugs.He’s got his le back, basically. It does happen.Soyou are worried about homelessness, think about donating to an organisation such as WLM. Better yet, volunteer your time and skills.Even just helping someone to fill out a form, which can be incredibly dficult for some people, can make a huge dference and is so rewarding.TODAY is Remembrance Day and I wear my poppy with pride. This year I will particularly recognise all the true heroes from World War One. I thank them for their service, and remember we are always in their debt.It is so important we never forget the sacrice they made and the bravery they showed.I doubt there will ever be another generation like them. AS a rule, I like to live and let live. But I really had to roll my eyes at the story of -year-old Dutch pensioner Emile Ratelband, “who identies as a -year-old” and is fighting to legally change his age by  years so he can get more work and attract more women on Tinder.Emile, above, was born on March , , but says he feels at least  years younger and wants to change his birth date to March , .His argument is thattransgender people are allowed to change sex, he should be allowed to change his date of birth because doctors said he has the body of a -year-old.So does that meanI feel like a supermodel inside, I can I get my job title legally amended Or maybe at  I could identy as  so I can have access to my pension SO the six men arrested for burning an effigy of Grenfell Tower are in hiding and relying on friends and relatives to bring in food and drink. Still, they are yet to speak out – or apologise.What beggars belief is not just that these sick men thought that no one would notice nor care when this footage emerged on social media – but really that they are unhinged enough to do it in the first place.I’m pretty sure about one thing, though. No matter what consequences they will face for their actions from the law, they will never, ever live this down in the eyes of the world – and nor should they.I’m talking about Michael Douglas, . When he was awarded with a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame for more than  years in the entertainment industry, he gave his father, Kirk, a kiss on the lips to celebrate.In my experience there comes an age when your kids don’t want to kiss you – particularly on the lips and particularly your dad.It’s part and parcel of growing up that your kids don’t even want you to breathe, let alone kiss them.In fact, everything you do embarrasses them. But, given that Kirk Douglas is , maybe it’s just a reminder that things come full circle.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: apprentice airline best episode years
story: It split apart million years ago and, must confess, it had entirely escaped my notice before Wednesday night — when it became the fourth-worst ever suggestion for the name of an airline, behind Black Box, Crash Positions and Ryanair.Or it was until Sabrina, from team Collaborative, came up with something that was worse than all of them — Jet Pop Airlines — and added a little explosion in the logo, just to set passengers’ minds fully at rest.No one involved should beat themselves up over any of these decisions, though, as they helped create the best episode of The Apprentice in years.It probably needed to be, as well. I sense, like the recently axed Big Brother and The X Factor, it’s been living off its reputation for a couple of years.Enjoyable as it’s been, the basic issue with this run has been the lack of a central figure in the mould of Syed Ahmed, Katie Hopkins or the late, great Stuart Baggs to take the series by the scruff of the neck.Some have shown vague promise but the closest thing it’s had to an alpha bell-end is Captain Pangea himself, Kurran Pooni, who was marked out less by his all-round uselessness than by the wrist he broke arm-wrestling back at the house, and his insistence he was “ per cent stepping up as project manager” just before he  per cent stepped down.There was no dodging the bullet, though, last week, when Lord Sugar demanded he PM a marketing campaign “for a noo airline” with accompanying adverts “and a noo unorm as well”.Kurran wasn’t underselling the sense of destiny he felt at this responsibility. “Everything in my le has led to this moment,” he claimed, presumably ’cos he hadn’t done anything  up until that moment.The great thing about this task, though — like all the best Apprentice episodes — was that the laughs were shared round equally.So while advert director Kurran was recreating the Club Tropicana video on Southend seafront, Camilla and Jackie were designing a stewardess’s unorm for the party-themed Jet Pop that wouldn’t see the light of day eveneasyJet suddenly opened a brothel chain in Amsterdam.A horrible thought occurred, though, as she was market-researching at Heathrow.She’s not going to wear that thing pitching to  industry experts at BA HQ, is she  She bloody is, you know.She gave it the full doors-to-manual flirtation as well. So everyone’s mind was already in the gutter before Jackie finished the audience off with the news: “It’s very easy to wipe down, as well.”In the normal course of events, reducing Claude Littner to a helpless giggling wreck would be enough to lose any task.The other team, though, Typhoon, had contrived to come up with something almost as bad, Manage Air, a business-targeted operation whose corporate logo looked like a satanic pentangle and theme tune was AC DC’s Highway To Hell.There was a genuine sense of tension in the boardroom then, which would’ve been ruinedSugar had played it all for laughs.He didn’t, though. He let the contestants hang themselves with their own words before firing Kurran, who could leave with a sense of “job done”.He’s created a bit of Apprentice folklore, after all, and hopefully reminded everyone this show is far from dead.Naturally, in the final taxi scene, he also remained convinced of his genius, boldly declaring: “My advert was gold.”The first and possibly last time in his le where he’s not just  per cent wrong, he’s  per cent right as well.Glorious television.Dianne: “Stephen Fry.”The Time It Takes, Joe Lycett: “Sesame Street’s Big Bird lives in what street ”Oliver: “I don’t know.”Joe Lycett: “A bird in the hand is worth two in the what ”Jon: “Foot.”And Bradley Walsh: “Which former EastEnders star presents the Sky One series Extreme World ”Zoe: “Barbara Windsor.”CELEBRITY Hunted contestant and former Commando Johnny Mercer MP has faced a stark choice this past month.The eternal humiliation of being beaten by Chris and Kem, off Love Island, on the Channel  hide ’n’ seek game.Or two weeks in a confined space with a clearly smitten Kay Burley.Heroically, he chose the latter, enduring her attention and pet namewith the same sort of grit that probably saw him through three tours of Afghanistan.Then, last week, he sneaked off for an unscheduled visit to his we, Felicity, and Burley completely lost her s***.Lost it so badly, in fact, that she threw herself at the mercy of a passing bread truck driver, which led to the best update of the series: “Kay Burley is currently in a -ton lorry, on the M, between junction  and .”She was quickly grassed up, of course, then apprehended at the Warburton’s depot, without the need for a vet or a tranquilliser dart.But while it’s a poorer show without the old mad-whack, there’s still plenty of mileage left in this gripping series.AJ Pritchard is cornered in Shropshire, Olympic silver medallist Louis Smith has just been found hiding in his mate’s Jacuzzi showroomand Baldrick-brained duo Chris  Kemhave somehow given everyone the slip.But as for Johnny Mercer  He’s probably smuggling himself back to the Mouth of Hell fort, in southern Helmand, just for the relative peace and quiet. Paul Merson: “For me it’s six and a half of one and a dozen of the other.”Graeme Souness: “The only one with potential is Martial and Pogba.”Dion Dublin: “Liverpool are in second and a half gear.”And Charlie Nicholas: “Pogba’s either brilliant or a showpony. He played OK last week.”THIS week’s Doctor Who episode introduced us to the Demons Of The Punjab, who turned out to be nothing of the sort.They were just morbid sods who mope around the universe “honouring those who die alone”, like soldiers, holy men and Brendan O’Carroll on For Facts Sakes.No actual science-fiction storyline to speak of then.But that’s not really the point of this viewer-shedding series, which has already got on its high horse about sexism, Donald Trump, American segregationist racism, men giving birth and gun control.Kind of inevitable, then, that the BBC would eventually pour a bucket of its self-loathing sick all over the British Empire, via the partition of India in , with an episode that was every bit as historically powerful as Carry On Up The Khyber.The key dference, of course, was that Bungdit Din and his Burpers weren’t actually being used as a means of brainwashing children.Because If you were expecting Doctor Who to present the flip side of Britain’s relatively benign rule in India , then you’ll also be waiting for the episode where Jodie Whittaker lands in a Soviet gulag and starts teaching children about the brutal idiocy of Marxism.The BBC just doesn’t do anything other than its own left-of-centre view, these days – or irony by the sounds of things.As it’s just been revealed there’ll be no festive episode of Doctor Whobecause it’s “run out” of storylines.Run out  RUN OUT How the hell can a series run out of ideas when it hasn’t had any yet This Morning, Thursday: “Coming up, at quarter to , the rise of the penis filler, Doctor Ranj is here to answer your questions.”The show’s other penis filler, Martin Lewis, will answer them on Monday.IT seems almost wrong to single out just one programme from Sunday’s beautul Armistice Day coverage, but the year’s most meaningful TV awards should probably all go to BBC’s They Shall Not Grow Old, made by Peter Jackson, whose astonishing film gave a voice, laughter, tears and colour to some of the extraordinary men who survived the - trenches.Those of us who watched it, on Sunday, are unlikely ever to forget the experience. Those of you who didn’t, must catch up with it on the BBC iPlayer.Be sure, though, to watch it right through to the credits’ last chorus of Mademoiselle From Armentières, where it names the veterans who have all long since passed but whose memories and souls have never seemed more alive and unforgettable.“It’s quite hard to put your finger on it.”I’ll bet.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: martin lewis free financial education textbook
story: Well, no, actually. It’s far more important than that. Money is an issue of wellbeing.Financial problems are one of the biggest contributors to orce, mental health issues, losing the roof over your head, custody of children and even suicide. And our nation has a real problem with financial capability.That’s why I passionately believe all our children should have financial education at school. While some may say it’s the parents’ responsibility, that doesn’t work when so many parents are struggling to understand financial issues themselves.In , I was involved in leading the successful campaign to get financial education on the English national curriculum, split across Maths and Personal, Social, Health and Economic education .It hasn’t made much dference. The Government put no resources into it.So we kept campaigning. Last year the Government said it would love to see a textbook, but couldn’t or wouldn’t fund it.So I made a donation to cover all costs to the Young Money charity. And last week, , free copies of the first curriculum-mapped financial education textbook Your Money Matters was sent to every English state school .It covers saving, budgeting, borrowing, working, tax, student finance, risk and reward, security and fraud and a lot more. It’s also available as a free PDF.I’ve been surprised at how many grown-ups have downloaded it to go through it with their kids, but ended up telling me they’ve learned something too.Companies spend billions advertising, marketing and teaching their staff to sell, yet we don’t get ANY buyers’ training. That needs to change. Yet the textbook by itself won’t do that.Soyou’re a parent, politely ask a teacher or headteacherthey got the textbook . . .  and plan to use it.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: the most common ways brits avoid getting the drinks in and weve all done it
story: Researchers who polled , UK adults found many shirkers have tactics they employ which means they go home having had a cheap night out - including claiming to have no money.Promising  Ill pay you back later – despite having no intention of ever doing so – and making out theyre too drunk to know its their turn at the bar are also common strategies.The research was commissioned by Pingit, an app which enables users to easily make fast payments and to split bills using just a mobile number.Darren Foulds of Pingit, said: “As we head towards the party season, it’s inevitable that we’ll end up sharing rounds, meals and taxis with our loved ones.And sometimes settling up is not as easy as we’d hope.The research also found four in  Britons have a friend who regularly avoids paying their fair share on nights out.And  per cent believe being tight with money is one of the worst traits a friend can have - although half have themselves been called out by pals for their penny-pinching ways.Being frugal on nights out is considered to be more annoying than those who take selfies every few minutes and those who incessantly check their mobile phones.A third feel so strongly about this they have even fallen out with a pal because of their stingy ways.During the past  months, those polled have found themselves down £ in total as a direct result of mates not buying rounds or paying their way during nights out.And more than half have lent money to mates - never to see it again.So to put an end to this many of those polled have come-up with ways of ensuring their friends buy a round or pay their portion of the bill.These strategies include excluding them from future rounds, threatening not to invite them out again and calling them out in front of everyone.Foulds added: “The research shows that we have a iety of ways to get mates to pay their share, but the last thing we want is to spoil the festive cheer.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
