title: theresa may brexit deal cabinet meeting
story: The PM is holding a crunch Cabinet showdown this afternoon where she will set out the details of the agreement shes struck with Brussels.A number of pro-Brexit ministers are feared to be on the brink of walking out over the deal.But before that meeting she had to take Prime Ministers Questions in the House of Commons - where MPs on all side tore into the proposed agreement.And Mrs Mays crisis deepened as a leaked memo revealed the EU has boasted of keeping all the controls over Britain after Brexit.Michel Barniers deputy threatened to use the controversial Irish backstop arrangement to make sure Britain is tied to the EU customs union for years to come.On a day of high drama in Westminster:If the Cabinet does block Mrs Mays deal today, she could find her position is untenable - leading to a Tory leadership crisis.Top Brexiteers have warned the PMs time is running outshe insists on pressing ahead with the current withdrawal agreement.And the DUP, which Mrs May relies on for her majority, said they wouldnt vote for the deal as it stands now.During Prime Ministers Questions this afternoon, the PM was assailed from all sides over her Brexit plans.Jeremy Corbyn blasted: After two years of bungled negotiations, from what we know of the Governments deal its a failure in its own terms.Tory Brexiteer Peter Bone told Mrs May: You are not delivering the Brexit people voted for and today you will lose the support of many Conservative MPs and millions of voters across the country.And Ken Clarke called on her to put Parliament first by keeping MPs in the loop - instead of hatching agreements behind closed doors.Last night Cabinet ministers were called into Downing Street one by one to examine the details of the agreement.They will meet at No at pm, where Mrs May will ask them to approve the deal.Brexiteers Penny Mordaunt and Esther McVey are seen as the most likely ministers to resign rather than back the PM.Today Mrs May was hit by a damaging leak - as it emerged senior Eurocrats are crowing about pulling the wool over Britains eyes.Sabine Weyand, deputy to EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier, reportedly told European ambassadors the aim is to keep the UK in the customs union for ever.A memo leaked to The Times claims she said: We should be in the best negotiation position for the future relationship. This requires the customs union as the basis of the future relationship.“They must align their rules but the EU will retain all the controls. They apply the same rules. UK wants a lot more from future relationship, so EU retains its leverage.The Sun was the first to report last week that Brussels still plans to force a customs union on the UK.Boris Johnson responded to the news with fury this morning, saying: Cabinet must live up to its responsibilities and stop this deal.NEXT FEW DAYS: EU diplomats study the text of the deal and flag up any problemsLATE NOVEMBER OR EARLY DECEMBER: EU leaders attend an emergency summit in Brussels where all  heads of government will sign off on the treatyBEFORE CHRISTMAS: Parliament votes on the withdrawal agreement - PM faces moment of truth as she attempts to head off Brexiteer rebellionFEBRUARY : The European Parliament holds its own vote on the dealMARCH , : The UK officially leaves the EU - but nothing will changethe withdrawal agreement has been arranged, because it will include a -month transition periodEARLY : Talks begin in earnest on the final trade deal which will govern the future relationship between Britain and the EUDECEMBER , : The transition period ends, and Britain leaves the European single market and customs unionJacob Rees-Mogg, chairman of the pro-Brexit European Research Group, last night said he could launch a bid to topple Mrs May.He told the BBC: There comes a point at which the policy and the inidual become so intimately connected that it will be very hard to carry on supporting this policy.And askedhe would write a letter calling for a vote of confidence in the leader, Mr Rees-Mogg replied: Not in the next  hours.Ex-leader Iain Duncan Smith suggested Mrs Mays days are numberedshe signs a deal which undermines the Union.Senior DUP figures told the PM they wont back the agreementit ides Northern Ireland from Great Britain, or keeps the UK in the customs union indefinitely.MP Jeffrey Donaldson said: This is not the right Brexit because it doesnt give the United Kingdom as a whole the opportunity to pursue free trade deals and control its own future.From what we have seen and heard, we do not believe that this deal is the best deal.THE controversial Irish backstop plan is the element of Theresa Mays deal which is most likely to cause fury among MPs.The mechanism is designed to ensure there is never a hard border between Northern Ireland and the Republic.Britain and the EU hope to agree a technological solution to the border problem during trade talks over the next two years.The backstop is a legally binding arrangement which keeps the border open eventhose efforts fail.Leaked details of Mrs Mays deal suggest that it will keep Britain tied to the EU customs union until an alternative solution is found.The whole UK would continue to follow European rules on customs - and Northern Ireland would stay tied to EU regulations even more closely.But the backstop would not involve checks on goods travelling between Britain and Northern Ireland.The UK has been denied the right to bring the backstop to an end unilaterally.Instead an independent  would rule on whether or not talks have broken down, and end the backstop arrangementso.Brexiteers are worried that the EU intends to keep the UK in the customs union permanently, using the backstop as cover for that.The partys Brexit spokesman Sammy Wilson added: We are clear - we will not be voting for this humiliation!Leader Arlene Foster is in London today - and told reporters the UK faces worrying times with Northern Ireland set to be cast adrt from Great Britain.Tory Remainer Jo Johnson, who quit as a minister last week, said the deal could lead to Cabinet resignations.He told an anti-Brexit rally last night: I talk to many MPs, colleagues in the Cabinet and where.I know how much they all think deeply about these issues and they are all looking deep into their consciences and thinking whether they can support this deal.Full details of the deal, which was agreed by British and EU officials in Brussels earlier this week, could be published this evening.Leaks suggest it will contain a backstop deal keeping Britain in the customs union for as long as there is no other way of avoiding a hard border between Northern Ireland and the Republic.Mrs May has apparently defeated the EUs attempts to impose a dferent customs regime in Northern Ireland.But under the backstop, the province would follow separate regulations on some goods.EU officials have reportedly said they want to use the backstop to trap Britain in the customs union for ever.In order to avoid that outcome, the deal will contain a review mechanism which the UK can triggerministers decide the EU is no longer negotiating in good faith for alternative outcome.Eventhe deal makes it through the Cabinet, Mrs May faces a huge challenge in convincing MPs to back it.

title: would the brexit deal hammered out by theresa may leave us under control of the eu
story: They claim the withdrawal agreement will make Britain a vassal state of the EU because it will force us to follow European rules permanently.But Mrs May’s allies claimed last night that while the deal is not perfect, it was “the best anyone could get”, and she has pulled off some key wins.They include throwing out a Brussels bid to enforce a customs border down the Irish Sea, and an independent  to arbitrate overthe Irish border backstop should end when either side stops acting in good faith.The most contentious final area of the deal is the backstop plan to keep the Irish border wide openno trade deal can be agreed before the -month transition ends.Talks have been deadlocked for weeks over it.But a breakthrough to solve the impasse has seen British wins including a UK-wide customs backstop only.The EU has agreed to strike its bid for a second backstop for Northern Ireland only to keep it alone within the customs union.There will be more dferences in regulations for the province – which will infuriate the DUP.But No sources insist movement of goods from Northern Ireland to the UK will continue unchecked without any barriers, as today.There will be no way for Britain to unilaterally end the backstop.But London will be able to trigger the clause – known in legalese as “best endeavours” –it feels Brussels has stop negotiating a trade deal in good faith and is just trying to trap the UK inside a never-ending customs union.An independent  will arbitrate over the good faith mechanism.Details are still to be confirmed, but it is likely to be a  of five - two from the EU, two from the UK and one from a separate country.Leaks of the draft text pointed to Britain being asked to swallow being bound tightly to EU rules for years to come - with some oversight by EU judges as a consequence.One Brussels insider told the FT that the dferent rules for Northern Ireland were still contained in the document but “disappeared from view”.But in order to secure a UK wide customs backstop the Government will be forced to sign up strict EU rules on state aid for companies and so called “level playing field” rules.TODAY: Cabinet meeting takes place at pm where the PM will ask her key allies to approve the agreement - the deal is likely to be published in full afterwardsNEXT FEW DAYS: EU diplomats study the text of the deal and flag up any problemsLATE NOVEMBER OR EARLY DECEMBER: EU leaders attend an emergency summit in Brussels where all  heads of government will sign off on the treatyBEFORE CHRISTMAS: Parliament votes on the withdrawal agreement - PM faces moment of truth as she attempts to head off Brexiteer rebellionFEBRUARY : The European Parliament holds its own vote on the dealMARCH , : The UK officially leaves the EU - but nothing will changethe withdrawal agreement has been arranged, because it will include a -month transition periodEARLY : Talks begin in earnest on the final trade deal which will govern the future relationship between Britain and the EUDECEMBER , : The transition period ends, and Britain leaves the European single market and customs unionApart from the backstop, most details of the withdrawal agreement have been known for several months already.It will see a transition period extending until December , .During that time the UK will continue to act asit is still in the EU, following all European rules and remaining in the customs union.The deal also includes an agreement for Britain to pay out £billion, to cover the costs we have already agreed to cover.And it will guarantee the rights of Europeans living in the UK, plus Brits in the EU - meaning they can carry on under the current arrangements for their whole lives.The deal cut this week will give few details of future trade arrangements post Brexit.The trade deal will be negotiated over the next two years - throwing up yet more potential headaches for the Government eventhe withdrawal agreement passes without a hitch.

title: schoolgirls given free tampons nottingham period poverty
story: City Councils in Nottingham and Bristol have voted to provide free products in schools to ensure pupils do not miss out on their education during periods.Notts and Bristol have also said they will also aim to encourage local businesses to provide sanitary products for staff.The move is a response to statistics that show some women are being forced to choose between paying the bills and buying tampons, while schoolgirls have missed school because they couldnt afford sanitary products.In Nottingham, the motion was put forward by Labour councillor Nick Raine after speaking to teachers on his ward.He said: It affects pupils education. A total of  per cent of young women say they have missed at least one day of school because they didnt have adequate sanitary protection, and some have missed more.He continued: Well work with schools and colleges so they dont need to miss school.As a council, this in our power to address. And it was about time, in terms of equality, to discuss these matters in public.In Bristol, Councillor Helen Godwin, who lobbied for the motion, said: This issue simply shouldnt belong in  and it is a travesty that we need to tackle period poverty in our city. Too many of our girls and women are unable to afford or access sanitary protection during their period.Godwin said she wants Bristol to be a trailblazer local authority in how they tackle the issue and will hold a period poverty summit next month to map out how to ensure that all girls in Bristol for Year Five to  can access pads and tampons in their school.She said they will also pledge to ensure that free sanitary products will be available from libraries and civic buildings, as well as encouraging local businesses to provide products to their workforce.It is my hope then that women and girls will never have to consider whether they can afford to have their period, she said.Charity Plan International UK has found that one in  girls aged  to  have been unable to afford sanitary products.A total of  per cent have had to improvise sanitary wear and  per cent of girls have changed to a less suitable sanitary product due to cost.Lucy Russell, Plan International UKs Campaign Manager, said: We welcome proposals and new ideas to help tackle the fact that for too many girls, dealing with their period each month is proving a tough challenge. Distributing products at school, including reusables, could play a role in ensuring that no girl struggles to afford sanitary wear.”

story: Proving that Brexit can ide families just as much as the rest of politics, Jo Johnson, brother of Brexit campaigner Boris Johnson, quit as a transport minister on Friday.He warned the UK was "barrelling towards an incoherent" orce and called for another referendum on the final terms of Brexit.A Remain-supporting minister in Orpington, where a majority of people voted to Leave in the  poll, Mr Johnson attacked the draft agreement for being "so radically dferent to what was proposed in the referendum campaign".:: David Davis, Brexit secretary Having led the UKs Brexit strategy from the beginning, David Davis announced he was standing down in July over the PMs Chequers proposal.The plan for the UKs future relationship with Brussels angered many Brexiteers.In quitting, Mr Davis, a veteran Tory MP, said he feared the UKs "negotiating approach" would only result in "further demands for concessions" from the EU.:: Boris Johnson, foreign secretary One of the biggest figures of the Brexit campaign, Boris Johnson also quit as foreign secretary over the Chequers proposal.

title: prince charles at 70 royal family releases official birthday photo
story: Prince William, Prince Harry and Meghan also feature in the family photos.The pictures were taken by Getty photographer Chris Jackson. He said: "I was delighted to have been asked to take these portraits of The Prince of Wales surrounded by his family to celebrate the important milestone of his th birthday."It was particularly special to capture such an informal and relaxed family portrait over a fun afternoon in the gardens of Clarence House."The pictures officially mark the princes th birthday.Born on  November , he has been heir to the throne since , when he was only three years old, after his mother became Queen following the death of her father King George VI.As Britains longest serving heir apparent he has redefined the role, championing causes including protecting the environment, architecture, supporting young people and inter-faith work.Applauded by some as a visionary, others have criticised him for straying into political matters.Last week in an interview ahead of his birthday Prince Charles denied suggestions he will be a meddling monarch when he becomes king, saying "Im not that stupid".Ahead of his birthday Sky News spoke to some of his contemporaries, and fellow baby boomers, about the impact the prince has had on society and what we can expect from him as a future monarch. Tony Juniper, from the World Wildle Fund, has worked as a special adviser on environmental issues and written books with him.He said: "He has built an incredible track record of being ahead of the curve on all sorts of subjects whether it was global warming, whether it was the loss of the tropical rainforests, whether it was the question of sustainable agricultural or plastics in the sea."Hes always been there setting the agenda # I thinkyou had to count the leading environmentalists of the past half century he would be amongst them possibly the top environmentalist."

story: NewsopinionIm A Bit Brexity, Get Me Out Of Here! amazing ways to make Im A Celebrity actually usefulShareCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV Newsopinion"Get Im a Celebrity updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailNick Knowles without a hard hat, Harry Redknapp without a football, Anne Hegerty with no-one chasing her. And Katie Flipping Price again. This years jungle reality show is on-course to be a fun-free retread, carefully read off the autocue with no ad-libbing by Holly Willoughbubbly and a sleep-deprived dad. But oh, how much better it would bethe producers had the wit, foresight and sense of public service to centre the whole thing on Brexit. There would be two benefits:  So much voting  If we cant make some of those responsible eat kangaroo testicles while we watch, then the nation will otherwise block out the most important consitutional event in our letimes As a happy bonus, Nigel Farage might explode. Whats not to like  There are many ways the producers could achieve a much better Im A Celebrity. For example: . Drop entire Cabinet into jungle via parachute packed by Edward Scissorhands . Realise this means Mogg is in charge, so send rest of Conservative Party as new campmate with secret mission to actually support the Cabinet infor knighthoods . Microchip the inmates, deny them access to sugary drinks, WhatsApp conspiracy groups, and the newspaper articles of Boris Johnson  . Order Ant McPartlin to narrate, without his lawyer or PR man, and having told him his we got the dog . Send in Nigel Farage, Arron Banks and any suspicious-looking Russian friends . Use TVs The Hunted team to track down all others loosely responsible for getting us into this mess, and send them to the camp via Hermes most devil-may-care service . Nuke the site from orbit. Its the only way to be sure And wouldnt the peace be wonderful - the silence of the Johnsons, the restoration of sanity, the knowledge wed never have to see Theresa May dance again. Perhaps Laura Kuenssberg and her colleagues could get on with covering everything  thats been screwed up. Perhaps we could elect some people to Parliament with a vague idea of how to fix things rather than making them worse. Maybe, even, wed have a moment of national clarity and notice that Brexit was an expression of unhappiness that cannot be followed through without wrecking everything, so best pretend it never happened and invite the French over for Christmas. So much better, more entertaining, and more cathartic for our current sickness of slathering self-hatred to focus it, for a few short weeks, onto those we deem responsible, bury them alive in coffins filled with snakes and spiders, and move into the new year freshly filled with joy. Whoops, missed one. Can we still get Katie Price in there too

story: NewsWhat is the Brexit backstop  Northern Ireland border plan explainedIf Theresa May resigns in disgrace, a boring technical thing called the backstop will be to blame. The backstop for the Northern Irish border. Youve probably heard a lot about this mysterious backstop. But do you know what it means  We dont blame younot, as the whole thing has been testing our brains for months. In fact, its astonishing that the whole of Brexit has come down to boring technical jargon about customs arrangements. No one told you THAT in . But we are where we are, and with a possible general election round the corner, its vital you know what the debate is about. Here is the issue explained.  The backstop is a small but crucial part of the overall Brexit deal.It is a backup plan to guarantee checks do noton the -mile border between Northern Irelandand the Republic . This situation - known as a hard border - would set Irish peace back decades and could trigger ato violence of the Troubles. It would reverse the Good Friday Agreement pact that allows anyone to cross the border with little more than a sign and a dferent-coloured road.  Under the backstop, EU customs rules will be extended across the whole of the UK for a temporary period. This has infuriated Brexiteer MPs - who fear we will be a vassal state to Brussels, unable to sign trade deals around the world. It will kick in from December no solution has been found for the Irish border. December : If theres a deal, this is when the transition period - which continues pretty much all the EU rules we have now - is supposed to end. But talk has been floated of extending this by a few months. After December : If theres still no deal, under current plans a backstop would kick in. This could keep the UK tied to EU customs rules, until a proper agreement is reached, in exchange for keeping the Northern Ireland border open. If this wasnt bad enough it could be overseen by the European Court of Justice - the exact body Theresa May is trying to leave.  EU negotiator Michel Barnier previously warned a deal could force some goods to be checked between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK. story: NewsBrave US couple pick gale-lashed Hebrides mountain for incredible wedding photosJames and Laura Mortier eloped from Chicago to the Isle of Skye for the amazing photo shoot, with the brides white dress soaked and covered in mudShareCommentsByDaniel Sheridan:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsThese incredible photographs show a wedding photo shoot with a dference "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA daring US couple eloped to a gale-lashed mountain in Scotland for an incredible set of wedding photos.James and Laura Mortier wanted the snaps of their special day to be dferent but they were in shock at how strong the winds were.The photographs capture the bride traipsing through muddy bogs in her stunning white wedding dress and with her bridal hair whipped up by gale force winds. And the groom is captured in the stark landscape, his neatly tailored wedding suit soaked through by sheets of rain lashing the crags. But the results of their bold choice of venue are a series of stunning images that capture both the raw beauty of the wilderness setting and their love for each other.  Newly-weds James and Laura picked the Isle of Skye after considering locations around the globe. James, , and Lisa,  flew from their home in Chicago to the picturesque island for the unique shoot following their Scottish wedding ceremony on September .The couple, who have been together for four years, got in touch with Andrew Rae - a Scottish photographer - on Instagram after viewing his incredible gallery of past images.However, the pair were hit with strong winds and a barrage of mud as they posed for the set. Lisa said the couple took a while to decide on their perfect destination to elope but after spotting pictures of the Isle, their mind was made up. Lisa added: We wanted a unique wedding experience that was reflective of us. We both love the outdoors and are always up for an adventure. She added: Our first destination thought was French countryside, but the more I researched it, the more dficult it seemed to be due to the language barrier. Scotland continually came up as an elopement destination and neither of us had been before so we just kind of went with it. Photographs of Skye really solidied it as the perfect place for us.  The couple prepared for the weather conditions and Lisa said she didnt mind getting her wedding dress covered in mud. She added: It was expected. I searched for the perfect dress that could pack well and was lightweight for hiking around for this purpose. We wanted to end up in the fairy pools, but due to the weather we never made it. I’ve been dreaming of Skye every day since.  The newlyweds grew up just half a mile away from each other Lisa said: We knew of each other in high school but connected well after college at a neighbourhood bar. We now own a home in the same neighborhood we grew up in.  Lisa said she would recommend a similar shoot to anyone who wants incredible wedding photographs. She added: We planned to marry at Loch Coruisk but could not make the trip due to bad weather. We chose to marry at Honeycomb Rock, an area near the pier to travel to Loch Coruisk. Andrew’s photography skills are truly an art form. I never imagined I would look at such a beautul photograph and see myself in it. story: NewsBritains filthiest home  Piles of faeces blocked doors in flea ridden houseNicola Lissimore lived in a filthy Wolverhampton home and has now been banned from keeping animals for le after admitting two animal welfare offencesShareCommentsByHayley Pugh:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsThe disgusting interior of Nicola Lissimores house"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailFour dead cats were found in a disgusting property so filthy fleas were jumping at the front door and piles of faeces were blocking the back door. The -year-old lived in a filthy house and the court heard how the RSPCA were called to her address after concerns a number of cats were not being cared for. Inspector Dawn Burrell went to the address and was unable to contact the owner but could see a number of emaciated cats through a window. The pets had no access to the outside and she could see fleas jumping up at the front door. The RSPCA monitored property for a few days and believed no one was attending to the cats so, upon veterinary advice, entry was gained with the help of officers from West Midlands Police. Inspector Burrell said once inside it was clear the cats were suffering from dehydration, were emaciated and had other untreated medical issues.  She said: The police went to the back door and couldnt push it in due to the amount of faeces behind it so we tried the front. This was one of the worst properties I have entered in my thirty years in the job.  It was so sad to see these dead cats just left in the filth and the others were either emaciated or had other health problems which had not been addressed. The surviving cats were signed over into the care of the RSPCA and have now been rehabilitated. Some have already found new homes and others are still waiting for adopters. Lissimore was also given a -week jail term suspended for  months. The woman, from Cheshire, was reported to police after she appeared to write on a secret Facebook group that she had used the potentially lethal treatment on her son.The highly-covert group is for parents who believe autism - a lelong, developmental disability - is caused by parasites. The groups , members, who are allegedly charged pound to join, share images of the so-called parasites leaving their children after treatment while congratulating themselves. But autism campaigner Emma Dalmayne claims the shocking images in fact show childrens bowel linings that have been burned out of their bodies by the bleach.  The treatment, known as CDor MMS , is administered orally or via enema and is being sold in the UK by online dealers and in person. Emma infiltrated the Facebook group and discovered the mother from Cheshire appearing to confess to using CD on her young son and reported her to Cheshire Police. Posts from the mum appear to show her admitting to administering  drops a day to her son, but becoming worried when he seemed weak and wouldnt get out of bed. Emma is calling for the government to ban the treatments and has launched at petition calling for alleged autism cures to be made illegal, which has more than , signatures.  Emma, an autistic mum-of-six from London, said: No parents will admit to doing this to their children publicly. This treatment is not illegal at the moment but we need to get rid of it. These parents are so ashamed of doing it in the first place. These people are brainwashed by [proponents of CD and MMS], who say that those against this support big pharma. The biggest problem is that the government dont do anything about this. This is not illegal yet. It is not illegal to use CD on your children and it needs to be. The most extreme case I have seen to date is a six-year-old boy who had to have his bowel removed and a colostomy bag fitted after his parents gave him these enemas. What you see in these images is the bowel lining of these victims. Some of the people who disagree with my campaigning have told me I should die, Im a whore, my children are vaccine damaged, I wont heal them because I want them to be autistic and I claim disability allowance so it wouldnt be profitable to heal them. It makes me so angry as an autistic person. Im furious that people want to heal this. There is no cure for autism. It isnt a disease or a disorder, its a neurological dference.  The Food Standards Agency issued a warning that both MMS and CD should be avoided and that the concentration of MMS is equivalent to industrial strength bleach. The mother, whose son is severely autistic, refused to respond to attempts to speak to her. A spokesperson from Cheshire Police said: This is an ongoing incident and we are investigating whether any criminal offences have taken place. Another parent, from Leicestershire, who claimed on the group that she had used MMS on her baby daughter, asked the group membersshe was doing alright because the baby was OK. The woman and her husband, both originally from Algeria, claimed they did not want to comment and had noticed how opinions y about this treatment. Her husband said: She is not happy to talk about. We are not there yet. I therefore have nothing  to say.  On the Facebook group, there is advice on how to make protocol , testimonials and also safe online practices information. Guidelines on the group that were published in  advise members that use of CD is beyond the mainstream standard of care and can get you into trouble. It also saystherapists, nurses or school officials come to your home please keep your supplies and dosing discreet. Recent posts from the website show concerned parents listing abnormal symptoms after administering CD to their autistic children. One mother posted: Hi everybody, my son has the last few days blue lips, is that normal . Others respond saying no, that is not normal. Check his heart. The concerned mother replied Im worried now. What can it be  But it started after we used CD.  On July , another parent posted a graphic image of her daughters dirty nappy with long pieces of bowel lining laid out on a piece of kitchen roll. The mother asks members to identy what parasite it is, and one respondent claims her daughter must be doing bettershe expelled this without even an enema. An admin posted this is good. story: NewsSurprising everyday palm oil products to avoidyou want to save orangutansSupermarket chain Iceland recently highlighted the plight of the animals through a banned advert as rainforests continue to be destroyed for the sought-after oilShareCommentsByDanya BazaraaNews Reporter:,  NOV NewsThe World Wildle Fund showed dferent products that may contain palm oil"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn Iceland advert recently highlighted the plight of orangutans as rainforests continue to be destroyed for palm oil.The high street supermarket shared the ad via its Twitter page after it was banned by watchdog Clearcast, which explained it is “concerned it doesn’t comply with the political rules”. The short advert, titled Rang-Tan, starts with a little girl wondering how to get a mischievous baby orangutan out of her room. But when she asks him how he came to be there in the first place, he shows the girl a digger ripping up trees as his mum lies dying. There’s a human in my forest and I don’t know what to do. He took away my mother and I’m scared he’ll take me too, the voiceover says. The supermarket chain has pledged to remove palm oil from all its own-brand products by the end of the year. But what is palm oil found in  There are some everyday products that contain palm oil that may surprise you.  Some kinds of lipstick are said to contain palm oil as it helps it hold its colour well. Shampoos could also contain it as the oil helps hair restore natural oils. Soaps and detergents could be found to have palm oil in them, as it removes dirt. Food products that could be found with palm oil inside include margarine, instant noodles, pizza dough, packaged bread, ice cream, cookies and chocolate, according to the World Wildle Fund.  Palm oil helps to give chocolate a shiny appearance and stops it from melting. It can give cookies and ice cream a creamy taste, and also enhances texture of bread dough. Some kinds of instant noodles also made it on the list WWFs list for containing palm oil.  Greenpeace has reportedly made a link between Mondelez - which makes Cadbury, Oreo and Ritz products - to the destruction of a big orangutan habitat in Indonesia. “It’s outrageous that despite promising to clean up its palm oil almost  years ago, Mondelez is still trading with forest destroyers,” Kiki Taufik, who leads Greenpeace Southeast Asia’s Indonesia forests campaign, told News.au. “Palm oil can be made without destroying forests, yet our investigation discovered that Mondelez suppliers are still trashing forests and wrecking orangutan habitat, pushing these beautul and intelligent creatures to the brink of extinction. “They’re literally dying for a biscuit.” According to the report, Mondalez bought at least , tonnes of palm oil and palm oil products in . A spokeswoman for Mondalez told : Mondelez International is committed to eradicating deforestation in the palm oil supply and we are actively working with our suppliers to ensure palm oil is fully traceable. We have actionable steps in place to make certain that the palm oil we buy is produced on legally held land, does not lead to deforestation or loss of peat land, respects human rights, and does not use forced or child labor. Mondelez will continue to prioritise suppliers that meet our principles and exclude those that do not. We are calling on our suppliers to improve practices across their entire operations and to engage their third-party suppliers to ensure their palm oil production is % sustainable and traceable. At the end of , % of our palm oil was traceable back to mill and % was from suppliers with policies aligned to ours. She added: While Mondelez International accounts for only about . percent of palm oil consumption globally, we have played - and continue to play - a leadership role in global industry advocacy toward sector transformation. We are proud to partner with several of the leading global organizations focused on improving the palm oil supply chain.  Regulators banned Icelands Christmas advert from TV screens for being too political - a move that has prompted , people to sign a petition for it to be allowed to be shown. The commercial, voiced by actress Emma Thompson and originally produced by Greenpeace, features a cartoon baby orangutan - Rang-Tan - warning its rainforest home is being cleared for palm oil plantations. Since it was banned it has had more than  million views on Facebook, the retailer said, and celebrities including James Corden have backed the campaign. The company pledged in April to take palm oil out of  food lines by the end of , a move which it said would reduce demand by more than  tonnes per year. Palm oil is mired in controversy, with warnings that sustainable versions are not preventing deforestation, while there are concerns that a switch to alternative oils could have greater impacts on habitat destruction where in the world.

title: desert drier mars devastated after
story: NewsDesert drier than Mars devastated after seeing heaviest rainfall in  yearsMicro-organisms in Chiles Atacama desert have struggled to adapt to a sudden change in climate in recent yearsShareCommentsByNeil Murphy:,  NOV News "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe worlds driest desert has been devastated after it saw rain for three consecutive years - the first time this has happened in  years. Northern Chiles Atacama desert has adapted to surviving without water for over  million years but unusual levels of rainfall have now seriously damaged the rare ecosystem and its uniques microbes. The region is constantly under observation from experts because the extreme dryness is regarded as a good analogue for Mars studies. As with Mars, the soil is extremely poor in organic le and yet it is still inhabited by microbial species from the three domains of le which are both dryness and radiation tolerant, and have lived in the region since the Jurassic period.  The situation in the hyperarid heart of the Atacama desert in northern Chile that has seen consecutive rains for the first time in  years has shocked scientists. Rather than supporting the development of le in the desert, they say the rain has destroyed it. The team from the Centre of Astrobiology say that the rain has devastated the microbial species that live there and were accustomed to no rain, according to the study published in Scientic Reports magazine. The recent rains have been attributed to climate change and investigator Armando Azua-Bustos explained: Our group has discovered that the contribution of water has not meant a development of le in the Atacama, has caused a huge devastation of the microbial species that lived in these places before the precipitation. They added: ... the sudden and massive input of water in regions that have remained hyperarid for millions of years is harmful for most of the surface soil microbial species, which are exquisitely adapted to survive with meagre amounts of liquid water, and quickly perish from osmotic shock when water becomes suddenly abundant.  The study said the indigenous micro-organisms that were perfectly adapted to live in the extremely dry conditions were unable to adapt to the new conditions and  percent of microbial le in the areas studied has been destroyed. The Atacama desert is one of the driest places in the world and is the only true desert to receive less precipitation than the polar deserts.

story: NewsFlesh-eating bug spreading across Australia is becoming more aggressiveBuruli ulcers, also known as Mycobacterium ulcerans, is an infectious disease which kills off skin cells, small blood vessels and fat under the skinShareCommentsByAbigail OLeary:,  NOV NewsExperts speculate the bug may be on the rise due to mosquitoes biting possums then biting humans "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA flesh-eating bug spreading across Australia is becoming more aggressive, according to doctors. Buruli ulcers, also known as Mycobacterium ulcerans, is an infectious disease which kills off skin cells, small blood vessels and fat under the skin. As the bug buries deeper into a sufferers body, ulcers begin to form before eventually a person is at risk of losing their whole limb. Cases of the bug are on the rise in parts of Australia, with Victorias Department of Health and Human Service raising concerns about the number of victims. Dr Brett Sutton commenting on the rise said: It may be that mosquitoes are biting possums and are biting people.  It might be that the possum faeces in the environment then contaminates it and people are getting it into their skin through cuts or scratches. In , there were just two cases of the bug, before this rose to  last year, reports nine.au. Experts are predicting this year will see  new cases of people infected by the flesh-eating bug. The bug can leave sufferers needing months of recovery. Jett, , had to learn to walk again after developing a Buruli ulcers that put him in hospital for three months.  His mum Arna-Leigh said: I remember the moment that the doctor came out of surgery. He said, I think that you need to go to Brisbane, and theres a real chance thatwe dont find out what this is, he will lose his leg. The Victorian government donated millionfor research on the ulcer and Dr Sutton said half has already been spent. The bug can often start as a small painless bump, similar to a common insect bite which grows and swells over a number of weeks.  The bump usually becomes painful and can lead to a mild fever before turning bright red and crusty - with a scab that wont heal. The scab then disintegrates as the bump turns into an ulcer. Treatment involves either oral antibioticscaught early enough or surgery to remove a small amount of healthy tissue around the affected area to get rid of the infection completely.In some cases, more complex surgery may be needed where a skin graft of health skin is transplanted over the ulcer.

story: NewsThis island has disappeared from satellite images - but did it really go missing The uninhabited islet of Esanbehanakitakojima was used to delineate Japan’s territorial waters but conspiracy theorists believe there maybe more to itShareCommentsByKelly-Ann Mills:,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news weird-news video island-disappeared-satellite-images-really-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe disappearance of a Japanese uninhabited island has caused conspiracy theorists to believe it hasnt simply gone underwater, but has instead just been deleted from satellite images. title: woman who can remember everything
story: NewsWoman who can remember EVERYTHING since  days old - including tastes and smellsEXCLUSIVE: Rebecca Sharrock, , has Highly Superior Autobiographical Memory and can remember everything from her first birthday to her school daysShareCommentsByElaine McCahill:,  NOV NewsRebecca Sharrock was born with Highly Superior Autobiographical Memory and can remember everything in her le since she was  days old "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMost people would love to remember everything - from how they felt at the happiest moments of their lives to the answers to exam questions.But for Rebecca Sharrock, never being able to forget is both a blessing and a curse. The -year-old was born with an extremely rare neurological condition that means she can remember nearly everything that’s ever happened to her in her le. Her first memory is of having her picture taken at  days old. And she can recall the minute details of her first birthday party - from the itchy satin dress she wore to the Minnie Mouse teddy that terried her. While some memories are more vivid than others, Rebecca can always remember the emotions she felt - as well as the tastes and smells she encountered. Her mind is filled with endless flashbacks - from magical Christmases as a child to more hurtful memories of her being bullied at school. The young woman, from Brisbane, Australia, told : “My memories are all in sequence, they come in a chronological order by days and times. “My earliest memory is of having my picture taken at  days old. “I saw a picture of that photo when I was  but I always remembered it and would speak to my mum about it in my early childhood. She was shocked that I could remember and when I saw the photo, it was dated the rd of December  when I was  days old. “It never occurred to me that it wasn’t normal to remember things like that.  Rebecca is one of around only  people in the world who have Highly Superior Autobiographical Memory , or a super memory.While her happy memories are wonderful, she admits it’s tough being able to recall every detail of her le - from what clothes she was wearing to exactly how she felt when something bad or embarrassing happened to her on a certain day. Her over-active mind also causes her to suffer from headaches and insomnia - but she has learned to quieten her mind by reading the Harry Potter novels. She now knows all the books by heart and recites them in her mind to calm her down and help her fall asleep. “The memories make it dficult to get to sleep when it’s dark and silent because I just get distracted, she told us. It happens all through the day but when I’m trying to sleep I just get random flashbacks and it keeps me awake. That’s why I learned to recite the Harry Potter books. While remembering everything certainly has its perks, Rebecca says her mind often feels “overwhelmed” and cluttered with memories. A particularly negative recollection can often ruin her day. She is currently in therapy and is working on ways to repress particularly painful memories and keep the incessant flashbacks at bay. “There are a few memories from my early childhood that are the absolute worst and I hate reliving those, said Rebecca. I want to get rid of those memories because I was going through a phase of depression when I was  and I don’t like reliving those emotions and feelings again. “When they’re negative, I like to call them intrusive memories. It could be a day I was looking forward to but something could remind me of a negative memory and the negative emotions flood back and it just ruins the whole day for me.  “I’ve been doing therapy for the past few years and my therapist has given me exercises to deal with my memories and they’re used for people suffering from PTSD. “One is called leaves on a stream, I just imagine taking every thought out of my mind and putting it on a leaf and it’s floating away. That just grounds my mind. While some of us still cringe at memories from our embarrassing teenage years, they flood back for Rebecca asits happening right then and there all over again. The intense experience can be incredibly painful and dficult to cope with over and over again. “I dream about my past all the time too, and they’re always about my school days, said the young woman. “I just relive the embarrassment of whenever I did something at school. Emotions come back, physical sensations come back, tastes and smells do as well.  Rebecca also tries to centre her mind by drawing her memories or building her Harry potter Lego set. When a memory comes flooding back, she has to fight the urge to respond in the same way she would have at that time of her le. She explained: “The emotions and the adrenaline I getto whatever age I was at the time of the memory but my conscience and reasoning are like an adult. That makes me feel ashamed and embarrassed and reluctant to be open about them because I know it’s an immature reaction or something silly that I don’t need to worry about. It creates a lot of confusion within me. In recent years, Rebecca has been working with neurologists to help with their research into how memory works. “I’m close to my step-dad’s family and his dad passed away two years ago from Alzheimers, she said. He had it for seven years before he passed away and it was just so sad. If there could be a cure, it would be fantastic. And I’m involved in research that helps find the answers and that means a lot to me. Rebecca has met one other woman who has H-SAM and says it was “incredible” to meet someone who has the same experience. “For the person not to be confused or amazed but just to react asit was a normal thing was amazing, she said.We just couldn’t stop talking the first time we met. It’s so amazing to have a friend who knows exactly what I’m talking about.” While she sometimes wishes she didnt have such an incredible memory, the young woman says the happy memories make it worthwhile. Often, it can feel like time travel. I relive happy memories just as much as negative memories, she said “Those are the moments I’m grateful I have H-SAM, I relive holidays I’ve had, I love going to the Disney and Harry Potter parks. “Most of my happiest memories come from my adulthood and not my childhood.  “Most of my happiest memories come from my trips to Calornia. And although she feels her mind is “constantly cluttered”, she has never felt any other way. “It’s something I’ve grown used to but I knowthis happened to me suddenly I’d be absolutely overwhelmed and I wouldn’t cope with it, said Rebecca. “I get a lot of headaches, I get tired a lot but it’s something I’ve just accepted as part of my le. I’ve just grown used to it. “Whenever I’m getting stressed because my head is just going haywire or I’m having an intrusive memory I do wish I didn’t have it but I like to focus on the positive. She added: “I used to look at it like it as a complete curse but now I’m teaching myself to look at the positive side.I don’t have to keep a diary to remember happy events - they’re just there.And it’s also something interesting to talk about - I love being quirky.

title: st mirren showing has to be minimum level for us to avoid drop says dundee winger ralph
story: Saturday’s improved performance against St Mirren is the minimum level Dundee can allow themselvesthey have any chance of avoiding relegation, according to defender Nathan Ralph.The Dark Blues felt they let the Buddies off the hook at Dens Park at the weekend in the - draw in what the full-back called one of their best displays of the season.And he insists that has to be the standard they maintain for the rest of the campaign.Ralph said: “I think it was a chance missed. I felt like we played as well as we have all season.“We should have won the game and I felt we were the better team for most of it.“To not get the three points was disappointing but the manager said it’s definitely something to build on and we’ll look to do that.“When you are where we are in the table, the ball doesn’t seem to drop for you but you have to keep fighting through it.“The manager told us that Saturday was the standard now – we need to stick to it and make sure it doesn’t go below that.”The Dark Blues head into the international break still bottom of the Premiership with just four points to their name after picking up just their second result of the season.Despite their very poor start to the campaign, the players still have belief they can get themselves out of trouble and the work they’ve been doing under new boss Jim McIntyre will pay idends.“It’s still there, the players believe in what we are doing, that showed against St Mirren and everyone is buying into it, so I feel like it’s just a matter of time,” added Ralph.“The intensity has been really high in training and the manager definitely demands hard work.“I think we showed that on Saturday.“We’ve got the international break now and I feel like it would have been good to have another game this week and keep the momentum going. However, we’ll definitely be working on things over the next couple of weeks and look to improve on Saturday’s performance.”Ralph was something of a surprise inclusion against the Buddies, having been missing from first-team action since the end of August with a damaged hamstring tendon.The former Woking man admits he had a slow start to le at Dens Park in his opening games but put on an impressive show in just his third league appearance for the club.The left-back was strong in the air, confident on the ball and an attacking threat throughout Saturday’s - draw.The -year-old admits he was blowing a bit by the end after a tough game but was delighted to get a first  minutes under his belt in over two months.“It had been a while but it felt good to be back out there and, with the slow start I’d had at Dundee, it was nice to have a decent performance as well,” added the former Yeovil Town man.“It would have been nice to get the win, too, but you can’t have everything.“I felt alright by the end, not as bad as I thought I might be having been out so long.“It was just about getting through that first  minutes and it’ll get better from here.“It’s never nice to be sitting on the sidelines, especially with the way the results have been going. You feel like you want to help out where you can and obviously being injured, you can’t.“It had been a long time doing that so it felt good to be back out there and help us get a point on the board.“We need to build on that now.”

title: tom duthie false dawns could be over for arabs as current dundee united team showing grit and determination
story: As their team has struggled to get back to the Premiership, the last two-and-a-half years have seen Dundee United fans become used to  dawns.Under Ray McKinnon, by the end of  the Tangerines had battled back from a slow start to their first season in the Championship to move to the top of the ision and looked every inch automatic promotion contenders.It didn’t last and the next couple of months saw them slip off the pace and have to concentrate their efforts in getting up via the end-of-season promotion play-offs.It was a case of lightning striking twice a year ago when Csaba Laszlo took over.For a couple of months, United again looked the part only to quickly fall away with a string of horrible results that left them again facing the lottery of those post-season knockout games.The memories of those campaigns are why many Arabs are trying their damnedest not to get carried away by the progress their team’s been making since another new manager, Robbie Neilson, took charge last month.After a run of four wins and a draw, keeping feet firmly planted on the ground must be growing increasingly dficult. For the -plus who travelled to watch the weekend win at Ross County, it might be well nigh impossible.Because at the Global Energy Stadium on Saturday, Neilson’s Tangerines looked every inch the kind of side that finish top of this notoriously dficult of leagues. That was largely down to there being nothing pretty about this win.Under McKinnon, Laszlo and even Neilson already, United have shown when it comes to quality football,everything clicks there’s not a team in the second tier who can live with them.They can pass any side off the park, keep possession and conjure enough chances to comfortably win a game.For all but a few sides with genuine aspirations to win the Championship, however, that’s seldom enough. This is a ision where the team finishing first must also have the ability to grind out wins.It’s what St Mirren did last season, Hibs the one before and even Rangers found they had to be able to do as they got up two years ago.Even Neilson’s young Hearts side that galloped away with the title in  did, on the few occasions when necessary, show they could dig deep and battle for points.Now, and arguably for the first time since they dropped down from the top flight, it’s a quality United possess.They ended County’s nine-game unbeaten home run since the start of the campaign, not through playing the kind of football of which we know they’re capable, but by standing up to the physical challenge that’s always posed by the home side up there.Yes, United had to do plenty defending, but through a clear game plan, organisation and a willingness of players to put their bodies on the line, it was executed so well that, for all their territorial dominance, the Staggies had very few clear sights of goal.A nice bonus stemming from that fact was, for the first time in his short tenure, in the build-up to the game injuries were a signicant issue.Frederic Frans and Callum Booth were doubts last week and unable to train with the rest of the squad until a Friday session confirmed they wouldn’t make it. In William Edjenguele and Paul Watson, the manager found able deputies.He’s said since he arrived at Tannadice winning promotion would take a squad of highly committed players.He now knows he has that and try as they might not to, the fans must be getting excited.

I want to know that they can get to school and it is guaranteed. As long as we are covered.A council spokeswoman said the change was not costing the council any more money as it is ldquoon existing terms and conditions.ldquoStagecoach has given assurances about service quality and the council will be confirming details of services with Stagecoach before they are registered with the Traffic Commissioner.ldquoIn some cases there are slight alterations to services but generally they will continue with no change."Wednesday  Nov  : PM

title: Star fought off nerves for film premiere
story: THERE was a packed cinema waiting for Inverness actress Karen Gillan as she introduced The Partyrsquos Just Beginning, her first feature film as director, writer and star.Most usually seen at premiere events in gowns by top designers like New Yorkrsquos Vera Wang, Karen wore a less formal white T-shirt and black trousers ensemble for the Inverness Film Festivalevent.But the Jumanji and s Of The Galaxy star explained that she and her American producer Mali Elfman had bought their almost identical outfits in Inverness after their luggage was lost flying here from a Moscow film festival.ldquoI was in my pyjamas when I arrived in Inverness! Karen laughed.Her film has already been nominated for Scottish Bafta best film, best debut screenwriter in the Best Independent Film Awards and picked up an artistic achievement award at the Philadelphia Film Festival.The IFF audiencersquos excitement surrounding the screening of the film was matched by Karenrsquos, she revealed.In a short introduction to the film, Karen ndash with Elfman and actress Rachel Jackson ndash said: ldquoThis is the most nervous Irsquove been to show the film because this place is so special to me. Itrsquos where everything started!Karen then explained her transition from actress to screenwriter and film director with her movie.ldquoI wrote it six years ago and knew I wanted to write something based in Inverness. I also knew that the statistics of suicide in young men between  to  in the Highlands was higher than in the rest of Scotland.ldquoI found that a strange and weird contradiction because itrsquos such a beautul place to grow up and it has been voted one of the most idyllic places to live, in Europe ndash in the world. I wanted to explore that through fictional characters.After the film, which features many city locations, such as the cathedral, riverside and Raigmore underpass, IFF director Paul Macdonald-Taylor asked how easy it had been to set the film in Inverness.Karen said: ldquoThere was some pressure ndash not from Mali ndash to film in Glasgow where there is more access to a film crew, but I was adamant I wanted to capture the authentic version of Inverness."Inverness just looks dferent from Glasgow, though we filmed the interiors there. Two Christmases ago we came up and ran around the streets of Inverness filming with a skeleton crew and I was doing my own hair and make-up.The real Inverness features in a few ways in the film ndash Karenrsquos character Lucy has a strong Inverness accent, city actor Matthew Zajac is one of a group of well-known Scottish faces taking cameo roles. People misdialling for a helpline and being put through to the home of Karenrsquos lead character Lucy actually happened to Karenrsquos family in the past, she told the audience.Karenrsquos QA also revealed that on Malirsquos advice the actress had first begun to practise for her role behind the camera by making some short films, one now set to become her next feature film. She is happy juggling her roles in blockbusters with her own films, describing her own as passion projects.Film review at www.whatson-northWednesday  Nov  : PM

title: Young Inverness dancers step things up at prestigious competition
